#text=My daughter , who is 11 , has been asking me how to make origami animals .
#text=When I was a girl I liked to fold origami too .
#text=I really enjoyed all the colors and patterns available .
#text=I did not remember how to fold any animals so I suggested to her that we might find a book on origami from the library .
#text=We drove to the library and walked inside .
#text=I told her we could ask the librarian where we might find a book on folding origami , but I would rather teach her to find the book on her own .
#text=We headed over to the library 's reference computer and opened the library catalog .
#text=There was an area to search by the books subject , so we typed in Origami .
#text=I told my daughter to write down the location of the books that looked interesting to her .
#text=she found about 3 that she liked because of how the cover looked .
#text=Once we had the locations we went to the shelf to find the books , based on the book number , we knew just where to look .
#text=We found two of the three books we were searching for .
#text=Then we were ready to check out the books and head home .
#text=I got out my library card and we went to a different computer that allows you to check the books out , so you can borrow them and take them home for a few weeks .
#text=We scanned my card , and the books and the machine printed a slip that told us when to return the books .
#text=We took our slip and headed out the door to drive back home .
#text=My daughter enjoyed looking at the pictures and trying a few of the animals herself .
